---
title: 'Overland.06: Sea of Blue'
cover_title: Overland
path: /episode
date: 2020-10-12
summary: Kyle Bondo details how the biggest army ever assembled in North American moves across the Rapidan River and into the fabled Wilderness.
tags: ['episode', 'overland']
categories: ['overland']
thumbnail: ./overland.png
---

## Overview

It's May 3rd, 1864 -- Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant and Major General George Meade plan to move the 120,000 man Army of the Potomac is underway. They will move the Union War Machine under the cover of darkness, cross the Rapidan River far EAST of the Confederate Left Flank and make an end-run around to the Confederate Rear before Lee has a chance to react. It is a good plan except for three faulty assumptions: Assuming they can keep the movements of a massive army a secret, assuming that Lee's troops will take over 30-hours to move out of their defenses, and assuming that they can move their army quickly through the fabled WILDERNESS.

## Quotes

"The foe that held his guarded hills -- Must speed to woods afar;
For the scheme that was nursed by the Culpepper hearth -- With the slowly-smoked cigar—
The scheme that smouldered through winter long -- Now bursts into act—into war—
The resolute scheme of a heart as calm -- As the Cyclone’s core."
-- Herman Melville: The Armies of the Wilderness - First Appearance in "Battle-Pieces and Aspects of the War" (1866), page 107 

"Whatever happens, there will be no turning back."
-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant

## War Yankee Supports

animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Overview</h4>\r\nIt\'s May 3rd, 1864 -- Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant and Major General George Meade plan to move the 120,000 man Army of the Potomac is underway. They will move the Union War Machine under the cover of darkness, cross the Rapidan River far EAST of the Confederate Left Flank and make an end-run around to the Confederate Rear before Lee has a chance to react. It is a good plan except for three faulty assumptions: Assuming they can keep the movements of a massive army a secret, assuming that Lee\'s troops will take over 30-hours to move out of their defenses, and assuming that they can move their army quickly through the fabled WILDERNESS.[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Quotes</h4>\r\n<em>\"\'Man proposes and God disposes.\' There are but few important events in the affairs of men brought about by their own choice.\" \r\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em>\"The foe that held his guarded hills -- Must speed to woods afar;\r\nFor the scheme that was nursed by the Culpepper hearth -- With the slowly-smoked cigar—\r\nThe scheme that smouldered through winter long -- Now bursts into act—into war—\r\nThe resolute scheme of a heart as calm -- As the Cyclone’s core.\"\r\n<strong>-- Herman Melville: The Armies of the Wilderness - First Appearance in \"Battle-Pieces and Aspects of the War\" (1866), page 107</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em>\"Well, the movement so far has been as satisfactory as could be desired.\"\r\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em>\"We have succeeded in seizing the fords and crossing the river without loss or delay. Lee must by this time know upon what roads we are advancing, but he may not yet realize the full extent of the movement. We shall probably soon get some indications of to what he intends to do.\"\r\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em>[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]\r\n<h4>War Yankee Supports <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a></h4>\r\nThe <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> knows that there is no substitute for experiencing history in the places where it actually took place and has worked to become the only one national organization working to save America\'s historic battlefields today and discover how you can help preserve American history forever. (2835, 1, '2020-11-07 06:24:13', '2020-11-07 06:24:13', '<h1>It\'s dawn on May 5th, 1864...</h1>\n...Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant, Major General George Meade, and the Army of the Potomac have spent the night in the fabled WILDERNESS. Now, as the morning sun rises on a new day, what started as an easy march out of the thickets quickly spins out of control after a series of unexpected enemy surprises.\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n<iframe title=\"Embed Player\" src=\"//play.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/16716893/height/200/theme/modern/size/large/thumbnail/yes/custom-color/2b3f55/download/yes\" height=\"200\" width=\"100%\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"\" webkitallowfullscreen=\"true\" mozallowfullscreen=\"true\" oallowfullscreen=\"true\" msallowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border: none;\"></iframe>\n<h4>Quotes</h4>\n<em>\"My pickets report nothing new from the enemy this morning.\"\n<strong>-- Brig.Gen. Wilson\'s Scouting Report Regarding Orange Plank Road from Parker\'s Store sent to Maj.Gen. Meade at 5:00 AM, May 5th, 1864</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"An unconfirmed report placed enemy soldiers on the Orange Turnpike. Concluding that Griffin probably faced an inconsequential rebel diversionary force. [...] I have no intention of modifying my corps\' movements.\"\n<strong>-- Maj.Gen. Gouverneur K. Warren, Commander, US Army V Corps</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"If they want to fight here, then we will fight here!\"\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"What had begun as a hopeful morning\'s march was rapidly taking an ugly, familiar turn. Once again, the Union high command had underestimated Lee\'s audacity.\"\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em>\n<h2>Support the <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a></h2>\nThe <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> knows that there is no substitute for experiencing history in the places where it actually took place and has worked to become the only one national organization working to save America\'s historic battlefields today and discover how you can help preserve American history forever. Join me in the fight to save our nation\'s historic battlefields by visiting the <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> website at <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">battlefields.org</a>.\n<h2>War Yankee Telegraph Department</h2>\n<ul>\n 	<li>Email Us: <a href=\"mailto:waryankee@gmail.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee AT GMAIL DOT com</a></li>\n 	<li>All our Show Notes: <a href=\"http://waryankee.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee.com</a></li>\n 	<li>All our Episodes: <a href=\"http://waryankee.libsyn.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee.libsyn.com</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"http://waryankee.com/\">War Yankee - Overland!</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\">Gagglepod - Until Every Story is Told!</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Wilderness#/media/File:Wilderness_May5.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Union Army Actions in The Wilderness (May 5th, 1864)</a></li>\n</ul>\n<h2>Follow the Action</h2>\n<ul>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/war-yankee/id1522169260\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on Apple Podcasts</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://podcasts.google.com/u/1/feed/aHR0cHM6Ly93YXJ5YW5rZWUubGlic3luLmNvbS9yc3M\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on Google Podcasts</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://open.spotify.com/show/0ZUjVf8xGNunKioJR2nGes\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on Spotify</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://waryankee.libsyn.com/rss\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on RSS</a></li>\n</ul>\nWar Yankee is a <a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Gagglepod</a> Production. animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Overview</h4>\r\nIt\'s May 4th, 1864 -- Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant and Major General George Meade have moved the vast Army of the Potomac across the Rapidan River and into the fabled Wilderness. Now at the end of their first day, the Union Army believes they are miles away from any real danger. When they wake on the morning of May 5th, 1864, they will soon discover a very different and dangerous situation that has emerged from the mystifying woods of Northern Virginia.[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Quotes</h4><p><em> \"There was something about the Wilderness that seemed to cloud \'Yankee Minds\'.\" <br /><strong>-- Gordon Rhea, The Battle of the Wilderness </strong></em></p><p><em>\"My pickets report nothing new from the enemy this morning.\"<br /><strong>-- Brig.Gen. Wilson\'s Scouting Report Regarding Orange Plank Road from Parker\'s Store sent to Maj.Gen. Meade at 5:00 AM, May 5th, 1864</strong></em></p><p><em> \"An unconfirmed report placed enemy soldiers on the Orange Turnpike. Concluding that Griffin probably faced an inconsequential rebel diversionary force. [...] I have no intention of modifying my corps\' movements.\"<br /><strong>-- Maj.Gen. Gouverneur K. Warren, Commander, US Army V Corps</strong></em></p><p><em> \"If they want to fight here, then we will fight here!\" <br /><strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em></p><p><em> \"What had begun as a hopeful morning\'s march was rapidly taking an ugly, familiar turn. (2838, 1, '2020-11-01 23:03:49', '2020-11-01 23:03:49', '<h1>So there I was...</h1>\n...a soldier in the Army of the Potomac marching towards the Rapidan River and into The Wilderness -- a 70-mile tract of thickets and dense forest. Only a year before May 1864, I had been at this same location when this same army was defeated at the Battle of Chancellorsville. Before I cross the floating bridge over the Rapidan River that will be later be torn up so that you cannot use it again to retreat... (2844, 1, '2020-11-02 21:40:56', '2020-11-02 21:40:56', '<h1>So there I was...</h1>\n...a soldier in the Army of the Potomac marching towards the Rapidan River and into The Wilderness -- a 70-mile tract of thickets and dense forest. Only a year before May 1864, I had been at this same location when this same army was defeated at the Battle of Chancellorsville. Before I cross the floating bridge over the Rapidan River that will be later be torn up so that you cannot use it again to retreat... a 70-mile tract of thickets and dense forest that only a year before had been the location of this same armies defeat at the Battle of Chancellorsville. (2850, 1, '2020-11-04 02:09:11', '2020-11-04 02:09:11', '<h1>So there I was...</h1>\n...an officer in the Army of the Potomac during the first week of the Overland Campaign leading men into The Wilderness against the Confederacy. As I struggled to maneuver my soldiers in a straight enough line to engage the rebels within this 70-square-mile tract of thickets and dense forest,  I keep asking myself: <em>How did I get here?</em>\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n<iframe title=\"Embed Player\" src=\"//play.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/16676399/height/200/theme/modern/size/large/thumbnail/yes/custom-color/75848c/download/yes\" height=\"200\" width=\"100%\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"\" webkitallowfullscreen=\"true\" mozallowfullscreen=\"true\" oallowfullscreen=\"true\" msallowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border: none;\"></iframe>\n<h2>Quotes</h2>\n<em>\"Let no man be so rash as to suppose that in donning a general’s uniform, he is forthwith competent to perform a general’s functions.\"\n<strong>— Prof. Dennis Hart Mahan, USMA (1824-1871)</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"[I] hail the day [I] left public office as the happiest of my life, except possibly the day I left West Point, a place I felt I had been at always and that my stay had no end.\"\n<strong>— Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant (1871)</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"I was always a friend of southern rights but an enemy of southern wrongs.\"\n<strong>— Maj.Gen. Benjamin Butler (1861)</strong></em>\n<h2>Support the <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a></h2>\nThe <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> knows that there is no substitute for experiencing history in the places where it actually took place and has worked to become the only one national organization working to save America\'s historic battlefields today and discover how you can help preserve American history forever. Join me in the fight to save our nation\'s historic battlefields by visiting the <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> website at <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">battlefields.org</a>.\n<h2>War Yankee Telegraph Department</h2>\n<ul>\n 	<li>Email Us: <a href=\"mailto:waryankee@gmail.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee AT GMAIL DOT com</a></li>\n 	<li>All our Show Notes: <a href=\"http://waryankee.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee.com</a></li>\n 	<li>All our Episodes: <a href=\"http://waryankee.libsyn.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee.libsyn.com</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"http://waryankee.com/\">War Yankee - Overland!</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\">Gagglepod - Until Every Story is Told!</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Wilderness#/media/File:Wilderness_May5.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Union Army Actions in The Wilderness (May 5th, 1864)</a></li>\n</ul>\n<h2>Follow the Action</h2>\n<ul>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/war-yankee/id1522169260\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on Apple Podcasts</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://podcasts.google.com/u/1/feed/aHR0cHM6Ly93YXJ5YW5rZWUubGlic3luLmNvbS9yc3M\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on Google Podcasts</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://open.spotify.com/show/0ZUjVf8xGNunKioJR2nGes\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on Spotify</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://waryankee.libsyn.com/rss\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on RSS</a></li>\n</ul>\nWar Yankee is a <a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Gagglepod</a> Production. animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Overview</h4>\r\nIt\'s May 4th, 1864 -- Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant and Major General George Meade have moved the vast Army of the Potomac across the Rapidan River and into the fabled Wilderness. Now at the end of their first day, the Union Army believes they are miles away from any real danger. When they wake on the morning of May 5th, 1864, they will soon discover a very different and dangerous situation that has emerged from the mystifying woods of Northern Virginia.[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Quotes</h4><p><em> \"There was something about the Wilderness that seemed to cloud \'Yankee Minds\'.\" <br /><strong>-- Gordon Rhea, The Battle of the Wilderness </strong></em></p><p><em>\"My pickets report nothing new from the enemy this morning.\"<br /><strong>-- Brig.Gen. Wilson\'s Scouting Report Regarding Orange Plank Road from Parker\'s Store sent to Maj.Gen. Meade at 5:00 AM, May 5th, 1864</strong></em></p><p><em> \"An unconfirmed report placed enemy soldiers on the Orange Turnpike. Concluding that Griffin probably faced an inconsequential rebel diversionary force. [...] I have no intention of modifying my corps\' movements.\"<br /><strong>-- Maj.Gen. Gouverneur K. Warren, Commander, US Army V Corps</strong></em></p><p><em> \"If they want to fight here, then we will fight here!\" <br /><strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em></p><p><em> \"What had begun as a hopeful morning\'s march was rapidly taking an ugly, familiar turn. Once again, the Union high command had underestimated Lee\'s audacity.\"<br /><strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em></p>[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]\r\n<h4>War Yankee Supports <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a></h4>\r\nThe <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> knows that there is no substitute for experiencing history in the places where it actually took place and has worked to become the only one national organization working to save America\'s historic battlefields today and discover how you can help preserve American history forever. animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Overview</h4>\r\nIt\'s May 4th, 1864 -- Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant and Major General George Meade have moved the vast Army of the Potomac across the Rapidan River and into the fabled Wilderness. Now at the end of their first day, the Union Army believes they are miles away from any real danger. When they wake on the morning of May 5th, 1864, they will soon discover a very different and dangerous situation that has emerged from the mystifying woods of Northern Virginia.[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Quotes</h4><p><em> \"There was something about the Wilderness that seemed to cloud \'Yankee Minds\'.\" <br /><strong>-- Gordon Rhea, The Battle of the Wilderness </strong></em></p><p><em>\"My pickets report nothing new from the enemy this morning.\"<br /><strong>-- Brig.Gen. Wilson\'s Scouting Report Regarding Orange Plank Road from Parker\'s Store sent to Maj.Gen. Meade at 5:00 AM, May 5th, 1864</strong></em></p><p><em> \"An unconfirmed report placed enemy soldiers on the Orange Turnpike. Concluding that Griffin probably faced an inconsequential rebel diversionary force. [...] I have no intention of modifying my corps\' movements.\"<br /><strong>-- Maj.Gen. Gouverneur K. Warren, Commander, US Army V Corps</strong></em></p><p><em> \"If they want to fight here, then we will fight here!\" <br /><strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em></p><p><em> \"What had begun as a hopeful morning\'s march was rapidly taking an ugly, familiar turn. Once again, the Union high command had underestimated Lee\'s audacity.\"<br /><strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em></p>[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]\r\n<h4>War Yankee Supports <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a></h4>\r\nThe <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> knows that there is no substitute for experiencing history in the places where it actually took place and has worked to become the only one national organization working to save America\'s historic battlefields today and discover how you can help preserve American history forever. animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]\r\n<h4>Overview</h4>\r\nIt\'s May 4th, 1864 -- Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant and Major General George Meade have moved the vast Army of the Potomac across the Rapidan River and into the fabled Wilderness. Now at the end of their first day, the Union Army believes they are miles away from any real danger. When they wake on the morning of May 5th, 1864, they will soon discover a very different and dangerous situation that has emerged from the mystifying woods of Northern Virginia.[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" animation_offset=\"\"]\r\n<h4>Quotes</h4>\r\n<em> \"There was something about the Wilderness that seemed to cloud \'Yankee Minds\'.\"\r\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, The Battle of the Wilderness </strong></em>\r\n\r\n[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Overview</h4>\r\nIt\'s dawn on May 5th, 1864 -- Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant, Major General George Meade, and the Army of the Potomac have spent the night in the fabled WILDERNESS. Now, as the morning sun rises on a new day, what started as an easy march out of the thickets quickly spins out of control after a series of unexpected enemy surprises.[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Quotes</h4>\r\n<em>\"My pickets report nothing new from the enemy this morning.\"\r\n<strong>-- Brig.Gen. Wilson\'s Scouting Report Regarding Orange Plank Road from Parker\'s Store sent to Maj.Gen. Meade at 5:00 AM, May 5th, 1864</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em> \"An unconfirmed report placed enemy soldiers on the Orange Turnpike. Concluding that Griffin probably faced an inconsequential rebel diversionary force. [...] I have no intention of modifying my corps\' movements.\"\r\n<strong>-- Maj.Gen. Gouverneur K. Warren, Commander, US Army V Corps</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em> \"If they want to fight here, then we will fight here!\"\r\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em> \"What had begun as a hopeful morning\'s march was rapidly taking an ugly, familiar turn. Once again, the Union high command had underestimated Lee\'s audacity.\"\r\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em>[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]\r\n<h4>War Yankee Supports <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a></h4>\r\nThe <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> knows that there is no substitute for experiencing history in the places where it actually took place and has worked to become the only one national organization working to save America\'s historic battlefields today and discover how you can help preserve American history forever. Join me in the fight to save our nation\'s historic battlefields by visiting the <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> website at <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">battlefields.org</a>.[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]\r\n<h4>War Yankee Telegraph Department</h4>\r\n<ul>\r\n 	<li>Email Us: <a href=\"mailto:waryankee@gmail.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee AT GMAIL DOT com</a></li>\r\n 	<li>All our Show Notes: <a href=\"http://waryankee.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee.com</a></li>\r\n 	<li>All our Episodes: <a href=\"http://waryankee.libsyn.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee.libsyn.com</a></li>\r\n 	<li><a href=\"http://waryankee.com/\">War Yankee - Learn more at <a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">gagglepod.com</a>.\r\n\r\n[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Overview</h4>\r\nIt\'s dawn on May 5th, 1864 -- Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant, Major General George Meade, and the Army of the Potomac have spent the night in the fabled WILDERNESS. Now, as the morning sun rises on a new day, what started as an easy march out of the thickets quickly spins out of control after a series of unexpected enemy surprises.[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Quotes</h4>\r\n<em>\"My pickets report nothing new from the enemy this morning.\"\r\n<strong>-- Brig.Gen. Wilson\'s Scouting Report Regarding Orange Plank Road from Parker\'s Store sent to Maj.Gen. Meade at 5:00 AM, May 5th, 1864</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em> \"An unconfirmed report placed enemy soldiers on the Orange Turnpike. Concluding that Griffin probably faced an inconsequential rebel diversionary force. [...] I have no intention of modifying my corps\' movements.\"\r\n<strong>-- Maj.Gen. Gouverneur K. Warren, Commander, US Army V Corps</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em> \"If they want to fight here, then we will fight here!\"\r\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em> \"What had begun as a hopeful morning\'s march was rapidly taking an ugly, familiar turn. Once again, the Union high command had underestimated Lee\'s audacity.\"\r\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em>[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]\r\n<h4>War Yankee Supports <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a></h4>\r\nThe <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> knows that there is no substitute for experiencing history in the places where it actually took place and has worked to become the only one national organization working to save America\'s historic battlefields today and discover how you can help preserve American history forever. Join me in the fight to save our nation\'s historic battlefields by visiting the <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> website at <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">battlefields.org</a>.[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]\r\n<h4>War Yankee Telegraph Department</h4>\r\n<ul>\r\n 	<li>Email Us: <a href=\"mailto:waryankee@gmail.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee AT GMAIL DOT com</a></li>\r\n 	<li>All our Show Notes: <a href=\"http://waryankee.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee.com</a></li>\r\n 	<li>All our Episodes: <a href=\"http://waryankee.libsyn.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee.libsyn.com</a></li>\r\n 	<li><a href=\"http://waryankee.com/\">War Yankee - Overland!</a></li>\r\n 	<li><a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\">Gagglepod - Until Every Story is Told!</a></li>\r\n</ul>\r\nWar Yankee is a <a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Gagglepod</a> Production. Learn more at <a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">gagglepod.com</a>.\r\n\r\n[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" (2871, 1, '2020-11-27 02:05:08', '2020-11-27 02:05:08', '<h1>It\'s the mid-morning of May 5th, 1864...</h1>\n...The Army of the Potomac has now discovered two massive rebel forces forming on both sides of Warren\'s 5th Corps still stung out over 5-miles within the tangles of The Wilderness. Now, as new intelligence arrives, they are becoming painfully aware that General Robert E. Lee\'s Army of Northern Virginia has launched a counter-crossing attack along the Orange Turnpike AND the Orange Plank Roads. As Meade falls back into his old Eastern Army habits by going on defense, will Grant be able to finally push the Army of the Potomac into an aggressive Federal position?\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n<iframe title=\"Embed Player\" src=\"//play.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/16971128/height/200/theme/modern/size/large/thumbnail/yes/custom-color/2b3f55/download/yes\" height=\"200\" width=\"100%\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"\" webkitallowfullscreen=\"true\" mozallowfullscreen=\"true\" oallowfullscreen=\"true\" msallowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border: none;\"></iframe>\n<h2>Quotes</h2>\n<em> \"What had begun as a hopeful morning\'s march was rapidly taking an ugly, familiar turn. Once again, the Union high command had underestimated Lee\'s audacity.\"\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em>\n\n<em> \"If [this] is what Meade meant by attacking \'at once\', as he said he would at 7:30 AM [it\'s now after 10:00 AM] no wonder Lee was running circles around him.\"\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em>\n\n<em> \"Double-Quick!\"\n<strong>-- Maj.Gen George Getty, Running to Brock Road Intersection, May 5th, 1864</strong></em>\n\n<em> \"We must hold this point at any risk -- Our men will soon be up!\"\n<strong>-- Maj.Gen George Getty, Arriving at the Brock Road Intersection, May 5th, 1864</strong></em>\n<h2>Support the <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a></h2>\nThe <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> knows that there is no substitute for experiencing history in the places where it actually took place and has worked to become the only one national organization working to save America\'s historic battlefields today and discover how you can help preserve American history forever. Join me in the fight to save our nation\'s historic battlefields by visiting the <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> website at <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">battlefields.org</a>.\n<h2>War Yankee Telegraph Department</h2>\n<ul>\n 	<li>Email Us: <a href=\"mailto:waryankee@gmail.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee AT GMAIL DOT com</a></li>\n 	<li>All our Show Notes: <a href=\"http://waryankee.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee.com</a></li>\n 	<li>All our Episodes: <a href=\"http://waryankee.libsyn.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">waryankee.libsyn.com</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"http://waryankee.com/\">War Yankee - Overland!</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\">Gagglepod - Until Every Story is Told!</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Wilderness#/media/File:Wilderness_May5.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Union Army Actions in The Wilderness (May 5th, 1864)</a></li>\n</ul>\n<h2>Follow the Action</h2>\n<ul>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/war-yankee/id1522169260\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on Apple Podcasts</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://podcasts.google.com/u/1/feed/aHR0cHM6Ly93YXJ5YW5rZWUubGlic3luLmNvbS9yc3M\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on Google Podcasts</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://open.spotify.com/show/0ZUjVf8xGNunKioJR2nGes\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on Spotify</a></li>\n 	<li><a href=\"https://waryankee.libsyn.com/rss\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Available on RSS</a></li>\n</ul>\nWar Yankee is a <a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Gagglepod</a> Production. Learn more at <a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">gagglepod.com</a>.', 'Overland.09: Defiant Blue Knot', 'The first critical events of the Battle of the Wilderness unfold as the Army of the Potomac discovers that it is about to be cut in half.', 'publish', 'closed', 'closed', '', 'overland-09-defiant-blue-knot', '', '', '2021-07-11 21:15:42', '2021-07-11 21:15:42', '', 0, 'http://waryankee.com/?p=2871', 0, 'post', '', 0),

animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Overview</h4>\r\nIt\'s the mid-morning of May 5th, 1864 -- The Army of the Potomac has now discovered two massive rebel forces forming on both sides of Warren\'s 5th Corps still stung out over 5-miles within the tangles of The Wilderness. Now, as new intelligence arrives, they are becoming painfully aware that General Robert E. Lee\'s Army of Northern Virginia has launched a counter-crossing attack along the Orange Turnpike AND the Orange Plank Roads. As Meade falls back into his old Eastern Army habits by going on defense, will Grant be able to finally push the Army of the Potomac into an aggressive Federal position?[/fusion_text][fusion_separator style_type=\"none\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" flex_grow=\"0\" top_margin=\"\" bottom_margin=\"3%\" width=\"\" alignment=\"center\" border_size=\"\" sep_color=\"\" icon=\"\" icon_size=\"\" icon_color=\"\" icon_circle=\"\" icon_circle_color=\"\" /][fusion_text columns=\"1\" column_min_width=\"\" column_spacing=\"40px\" rule_style=\"none\" rule_size=\"\" rule_color=\"\" content_alignment_medium=\"\" content_alignment_small=\"\" content_alignment=\"\" hide_on_mobile=\"small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility\" sticky_display=\"normal,sticky\" class=\"\" id=\"\" font_size=\"\" fusion_font_family_text_font=\"\" fusion_font_variant_text_font=\"\" line_height=\"\" letter_spacing=\"\" text_color=\"\" animation_type=\"\" animation_direction=\"left\" animation_speed=\"0.3\" animation_offset=\"\"]<h4>Quotes</h4>\r\n<em> \"What had begun as a hopeful morning\'s march was rapidly taking an ugly, familiar turn. Once again, the Union high command had underestimated Lee\'s audacity.\"\r\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em> \"If [this] is what Meade meant by attacking \'at once\', as he said he would at 7:30 AM [it\'s now after 10:00 AM] no wonder Lee was running circles around him.\"\r\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em> \"Double-Quick!\"\r\n<strong>-- Maj.Gen George Getty, Running to Brock Road Intersection, May 5th, 1864</strong></em>\r\n\r\n<em> \"We must hold this point at any risk -- Our men will soon be (2975, 1, '2021-07-11 02:17:38', '2021-07-11 02:17:38', '<h2>War Yankee – Overland is a podcast about Grant’s March South to Petersburg</h2>\n<h2>Listen to the Trailer</h2>\n<iframe style=\"border: none;\" title=\"Embed Player\" src=\"//play.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/15085049/height/200/theme/modern/size/large/thumbnail/yes/custom-color/2b3f55/download/yes\" width=\"100%\" height=\"200\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"></iframe>\n<h2>It’s May 1864...</h2>\n... and the Union has entered its fourth year of war against the Confederacy succession. President Abraham Lincoln has fired yet another General and promoted Ulysses S. Grant -- Hero of Vicksburg -- to General-in-Chief of the entire Union Army. Without delay, Grant forms a new aggressive strategy that will not only take the fight to the enemy but see him command the Army of the Potomac in the field.\n\nJoin US Navy veteran Kyle Bondo, as he follows the history of Grant’s Overland Campaign from Culpeper to Petersburg, Virginia, in his American Civil War podcast War Yankee. Learn what it took General Ulysses S. Grant and the soldiers of the Army of the Potomac to survive 40+ days of continuous warfare against the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia in 1864. War Yankee – Overland is a history podcast presented by <a href=\"http://gagglepod.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Gagglepod</a>.\n<h2>Why War Yankee?</h2>\nIt is a word my Grandfather used to call Ulysses S. Grant whenever it came up in conversation. He would say, “That Grant, he was the only War Yankee Lincoln had that was worth anything.” Or if the topic shifted to Sherman, he would say, “Good thing Grant had that Old War Yankee on his side.”\n\nI asked him once what he meant by “War Yankee” and told me, “It was a compliment — like calling a man a <em>War Horse.</em> Only a <em>War Yankee</em> IS a warhorse, another way to say there is a powerful force hiding inside a strong man.” This is why I named this podcast “War Yankee”. It is the standard that I want to hold myself to as well as making my Unionist point-of-view very clear from the beginning.\n\nBecause the Unionist point-of-view is an ideology that I was introduced to as a child and now fully embrace as a father, husband, veteran, and American. (3028, 1, '2021-07-11 02:35:39', '2021-07-11 02:35:39', '<h2>War Yankee – Overland is a podcast about Grant’s March South to Petersburg</h2>\n<h2><a href=\"https://podcasts.google.com/u/1/feed/aHR0cHM6Ly93YXJ5YW5rZWUubGlic3luLmNvbS9yc3M\"><img class=\"alignleft size-medium wp-image-2781\" src=\"http://waryankee.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/war-yankee-v7-meade-overland-400x400-1-300x300.jpg\" alt=\"War Yankee - Overland\" width=\"300\" height=\"300\" /></a>Forward, March!</h2>\n<h3>On May 3rd, 1864, General Ulysses S. Grant orders the Army of the Potomac to march South to being his Overland Campaign in Virginia. Grant is now the General-in-Chief of the US Army and will lead the Army of the Potomac South to meet Lee in an attempt to defeat the Army of Northern Virginia once and for all.</h3>\n<h2></h2>\n<h2>Major Battles</h2>\n<strong>May 3-4, 1864 - Crossing the Fords</strong>\nGrant takes command and heads South -- Grant moves the Army of the Potomac out of Culpeper and across the Rapidan and Rappahannock Rivers near Fredericksburg, Virginia.\n\n<strong>May 5-6, 1864 - Battle of the Wilderness</strong>\nGrant shows Lee that he is different -- The first battle between Grant and Lee in the woods and thickets of Northern Virginia.\n\n<strong>May 7-12, 1864 - Battle of Spotsylvania Court House</strong>\nLee blocks Grant\'s Move to the East -- A place where the bloodiest fighting of the Civil War takes place.\n\n<strong>May 13-25, 1864 - Battle of North Anna River</strong>\nLee\'s Trap Fails -- Lee beats Grant to the North Anna River but is unable to spring a trap that would have cut Grant\'s army into three pieces.\n\n<strong>May 26, 1864 - June 3, 1864 - Battle of Cold Harbor</strong>\nGrant finally gets Lee in the open -- The massive assault on the Confederate defenses at Cold Harbor does not go well.\n\n<strong>June 15-18, 1864 - Second Battle of Petersburg</strong>\nThe End of the Overland Campaign -- The second attempt to take Petersburg fails when Confederate reinforcements arrive and stop the assault.\n\n<strong>June 18, 1864 - April 2, 1865 - Seige of Petersburg</strong>\n10-month Seige of Petersburg -- Grant\'s forces encircle Lee\'s army at Petersburg and Richmond and begin to squeeze the Confederate defenders.\n\n<strong>April 2, 1865 - Third Battle of Petersburg</strong>\nEnd of the Seige of Petersburg -- The third attempt to take Petersburg breaks through the defenses and ends the 292-day siege.\n\n<strong>April 3-7, 1865 - Chasing Lee</strong>\nGrant chases Lee\'s army West across Virginia -- Grant\'s forces move to cut off Lee\'s dwindling army before it can escape to Tennessee.\n\n<strong>April 8-9, 1865 - Battle of Appomattox Court House</strong>\nGrant catches Lee\'s retreating army at Appomattox -- Grant\'s forces defeat Lee\'s dwindling army at Appomattox in one of the last battles of the American Civil War.\n\n<strong>April 9, 1865 - Lee Surrenders at Appomattox Court House</strong>\nGrant surrounds Lee\'s army  with two corps of Union soldiers -- Hopelessly outnumbered and cut off from escape, Lee surrenders his Army of Northern Virginia to Grant.\n<h2>Listen to the Trailer</h2>\n<iframe style=\"border: none;\" title=\"Embed Player\" src=\"//play.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/15085049/height/200/theme/modern/size/large/thumbnail/yes/custom-color/2b3f55/download/yes\" width=\"100%\" height=\"200\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"></iframe>\n<h2 style=\"text-align: center;\">* * *</h2>', 'Events', '', 'inherit', 'closed', 'closed', '', '1020-revision-v1', '', '', '2021-07-11 02:35:39', '2021-07-11 02:35:39', '', 1020, 'http://waryankee.com/?p=3028', 0, 'revision', '', 0),

Grant orders the Army of the Potomac to march South to being his Overland Campaign in Virginia. Grant is now the General-in-Chief of the US Army and will lead the Army of the Potomac South to meet Lee in an attempt to defeat the Army of Northern Virginia once and for all.\n<h2>&nbsp;</h2>\n<h2>Major Battles</h2>\n<strong>May 3-4, 1864 - Crossing the Fords</strong>\nGrant takes command and heads South -- Grant moves the Army of the Potomac out of Culpeper and across the Rapidan and Rappahannock Rivers near Fredericksburg, Virginia.\n\n<strong>May 5-6, 1864 - Battle of the Wilderness</strong>\nGrant shows Lee that he is different -- The first battle between Grant and Lee in the woods and thickets of Northern Virginia.\n\n<strong>May 7-12, 1864 - Battle of Spotsylvania Court House</strong>\nLee blocks Grant\'s Move to the East -- A place where the bloodiest fighting of the Civil War takes place.\n\n<strong>May 13-25, 1864 - Battle of North Anna River</strong>\nLee\'s Trap Fails -- Lee beats Grant to the North Anna River but is unable to spring a trap that would have cut Grant\'s army into three pieces.\n\n<strong>May 26, 1864 - June 3, 1864 - Battle of Cold Harbor</strong>\nGrant finally gets Lee in the open -- The massive assault on the Confederate defenses at Cold Harbor does not go well.\n\n<strong>June 15-18, 1864 - Second Battle of Petersburg</strong>\nThe End of the Overland Campaign -- The second attempt to take Petersburg fails when Confederate reinforcements arrive and stop the assault.\n\n<strong>June 18, 1864 - April 2, 1865 - Seige of Petersburg</strong>\n10-month Seige of Petersburg -- Grant\'s forces encircle Lee\'s army at Petersburg and Richmond and begin to squeeze the Confederate defenders.\n\n<strong>April 2, 1865 - Third Battle of Petersburg</strong>\nEnd of the Seige of Petersburg -- The third attempt to take Petersburg breaks through the defenses and ends the 292-day siege.\n\n<strong>April 3-7, 1865 - Chasing Lee</strong>\nGrant chases Lee\'s army West across Virginia -- Grant\'s forces move to cut off Lee\'s dwindling army before it can escape to Tennessee.\n\n<strong>April 8-9, 1865 - Battle of Appomattox Court House</strong>\nGrant catches Lee\'s retreating army at Appomattox -- Grant\'s forces defeat Lee\'s dwindling army at Appomattox in one of the last battles of the American Civil War.\n\n<strong>April 9, 1865 - (3051, 1, '2021-07-11 03:09:55', '2021-07-11 03:09:55', '<h2>Interpreting History</h2>\n<em>\"The problem with Civil War history is that all the letters home are going to have a bias. People have axes to grind, people want to make their buddies look good, and make themselves look good. The battle reports are all written from a point of view and, of course, all the reports written after the war read sort of like \'how I could have won the war if they had let me do it. All you can do as a historian is get all those accounts together read through them all, and see if there are some common threads.\"</em>\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, C-SPAN Interview with Peter Carmichael, June 20, 2014.</strong>\n<h2>Books</h2>\n<strong>Battle of the Wilderness</strong>\n<a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Battle-Wilderness-May-5-6-1864/dp/0807130214/ref=sr_1_3?dchild=1&amp;qid=1602174585&amp;refinements=p_27%3AGordon+C.+Rhea+Esq.&amp;s=books&amp;sr=1-3&amp;text=Gordon+C.+Rhea+Esq.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Battle of the Wilderness, May 5–6, 1864 by Gordon C. Rhea Esq. -- Overland Campaign Book Series (1 of 5)</a>\n\n<strong>No Turning Back</strong>\n<a href=\"https://emergingcivilwar.com/publications/the-emerging-civil-war-series/ecw-series-no-turning-back-a-guide-to-the-1864-overland-campaign-from-the-wilderness-to-cold-harbor-may-4-june-13-1864/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">No Turning Back: A Guide to the 1864 Overland Campaign, from the Wilderness to Cold Harbor, May 4-June 13, 1864\nby Robert M. Dunkerly, Donald C. Pfanz, and David R. Ruth</a>\n<h2>Online Sources</h2>\n<strong>American Battlefield Trust</strong>\n<a href=\"https://www.battlefields.org/learn/articles/battle-wilderness\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Battle of the Wilderness</a>\n\n<strong>Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum</strong>\n<a href=\"https://youtu.be/mr7CCG8488M\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Civil War Battle Series: From Wilderness to Cold Harbor with Dr. Mark DePue.</a> September 24, 2015\n\n<strong>C-SPAN - 1864 Overland Campaign</strong>\n<a href=\"https://www.c-span.org/video/?319537-1/1864-overland-campaign\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Peter Carmichael interviews Gordon Rhea.</a> June 20, 2014\n\n<strong>Warfare History Network</strong>\n<a href=\"https://warfarehistorynetwork.com/2018/12/21/grant-takes-d-c/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Grant Takes D.C.</a>\n\n<strong>Culpeper Star-Exponent</strong>\n<a href=\"https://starexponent.com/news/when-u-s-grant-came-to-culpeper-he-held-the-nations-fate-in-his-hands/article_d9d69e47-e69c-5be1-844b-3c6209b7eba2.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">When U.S. Grant came to Culpeper, he held the nation\'s fate in his hands.</a> April 13, 2019\n\n<strong>Herman Melville - The Armies of the Wilderness</strong>\n<a href=\"https://loa-shared.s3.amazonaws.com/static/pdf/Melville_Armies_Wilderness.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">First Appearance in \"Battle-Pieces and Aspects of the War\" (1866) [PDF]</a>\n\n<strong>Columbia - The Daily Herald</strong>\n<a href=\"https://www.columbiadailyherald.com/article/20140216/OPINION/302169932\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Robert E. (3075, 1, '2021-07-11 03:24:55', '2021-07-11 03:24:55', '<h1>The first critical events of the Battle of the Wilderness unfold as the Army of the Potomac discovers that it is about to be cut in half.</h1>\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n<iframe title=\"Embed Player\" src=\"//play.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/16971128/height/200/theme/modern/size/large/thumbnail/yes/custom-color/2b3f55/download/yes\" height=\"200\" width=\"100%\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"\" webkitallowfullscreen=\"true\" mozallowfullscreen=\"true\" oallowfullscreen=\"true\" msallowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border: none;\"></iframe>\n<h2>Overview</h2>\nIt\'s the mid-morning of May 5th, 1864 -- The Army of the Potomac has now discovered two massive rebel forces forming on both sides of Warren\'s 5th Corps still stung out over 5-miles within the tangles of The Wilderness. Now, as new intelligence arrives, they are becoming painfully aware that General Robert E. Lee\'s Army of Northern Virginia has launched a counter-crossing attack along the Orange Turnpike AND the Orange Plank Roads. As Meade falls back into his old Eastern Army habits by going on defense, will Grant be able to finally push the Army of the Potomac into an aggressive Federal position?\n<h2>Quotes</h2>\n<em> \"What had begun as a hopeful morning\'s march was rapidly taking an ugly, familiar turn. Once again, the Union high command had underestimated Lee\'s audacity.\"\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em>\n\n<em> \"If [this] is what Meade meant by attacking \'at once\', as he said he would at 7:30 AM [it\'s now after 10:00 AM] no wonder Lee was running circles around him.\"\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em>\n\n<em> \"Double-Quick!\"\n<strong>-- Maj.Gen George Getty, Running to Brock Road Intersection, May 5th, 1864</strong></em>\n\n<em> \"We must hold this point at any risk -- Our men will soon be up!\"\n<strong>-- Maj.Gen George Getty, Arriving at the Brock Road Intersection, May 5th, 1864</strong></em>\n<h2>Support the <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a></h2>\nThe <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> knows that there is no substitute for experiencing history in the places where it actually took place and has worked to become the only one national organization working to save America\'s historic battlefields today and discover how you can help preserve American history forever. (3090, 1, '2021-07-11 21:08:13', '2021-07-11 21:08:13', '<h4>Overview</h4>\nIt\'s dawn on May 5th, 1864 -- Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant, Major General George Meade, and the Army of the Potomac have spent the night in the fabled WILDERNESS. Now, as the morning sun rises on a new day, what started as an easy march out of the thickets quickly spins out of control after a series of unexpected enemy surprises.\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n[PLAYER]\n<h4>Quotes</h4>\n<em>\"My pickets report nothing new from the enemy this morning.\"\n<strong>-- Brig.Gen. Wilson\'s Scouting Report Regarding Orange Plank Road from Parker\'s Store sent to Maj.Gen. Meade at 5:00 AM, May 5th, 1864</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"An unconfirmed report placed enemy soldiers on the Orange Turnpike. Concluding that Griffin probably faced an inconsequential rebel diversionary force. [...] I have no intention of modifying my corps\' movements.\"\n<strong>-- Maj.Gen. Gouverneur K. Warren, Commander, US Army V Corps</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"If they want to fight here, then we will fight here!\"\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"What had begun as a hopeful morning\'s march was rapidly taking an ugly, familiar turn. (3099, 1, '2021-07-11 21:15:39', '2021-07-11 21:15:39', '<h1>It\'s the mid-morning of May 5th, 1864...</h1>\n...The Army of the Potomac has now discovered two massive rebel forces forming on both sides of Warren\'s 5th Corps still stung out over 5-miles within the tangles of The Wilderness. Now, as new intelligence arrives, they are becoming painfully aware that General Robert E. Lee\'s Army of Northern Virginia has launched a counter-crossing attack along the Orange Turnpike AND the Orange Plank Roads. As Meade falls back into his old Eastern Army habits by going on defense, will Grant be able to finally push the Army of the Potomac into an aggressive Federal position?\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n<iframe title=\"Embed Player\" src=\"//play.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/16971128/height/200/theme/modern/size/large/thumbnail/yes/custom-color/2b3f55/download/yes\" height=\"200\" width=\"100%\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"\" webkitallowfullscreen=\"true\" mozallowfullscreen=\"true\" oallowfullscreen=\"true\" msallowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border: none;\"></iframe>\n<h2>Quotes</h2>\n<em> \"What had begun as a hopeful morning\'s march was rapidly taking an ugly, familiar turn. Once again, the Union high command had underestimated Lee\'s audacity.\"\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em>\n\n<em> \"If [this] is what Meade meant by attacking \'at once\', as he said he would at 7:30 AM [it\'s now after 10:00 AM] no wonder Lee was running circles around him.\"\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, Battle of the Wilderness</strong></em>\n\n<em> \"Double-Quick!\"\n<strong>-- Maj.Gen George Getty, Running to Brock Road Intersection, May 5th, 1864</strong></em>\n\n<em> \"We must hold this point at any risk -- Our men will soon be up!\"\n<strong>-- Maj.Gen George Getty, Arriving at the Brock Road Intersection, May 5th, 1864</strong></em>\n<h2>Support the <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a></h2>\nThe <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> knows that there is no substitute for experiencing history in the places where it actually took place and has worked to become the only one national organization working to save America\'s historic battlefields today and discover how you can help preserve American history forever. (3101, 1, '2021-07-11 21:20:01', '2021-07-11 21:20:01', '<h4>It\'s May 4th, 1864...</h4>\n...Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant and Major General George Meade have moved the vast Army of the Potomac across the Rapidan River and into the fabled Wilderness. (3108, 1, '2021-07-11 22:33:20', '2021-07-11 22:33:20', '<h1>It\'s May 3rd, 1864...</h1>\n...Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant and Major General George Meade\'s plan to move the 120,000 man Army of the Potomac is underway. They will move the Union War Machine under the cover of darkness, cross the Rapidan River far EAST of the Confederate Left Flank and make an end-run around to the Confederate Rear before Lee has a chance to react. It is a good plan except for three faulty assumptions: Assuming they can keep the movements of a massive army a secret, assuming that Lee\'s troops will take over 30-hours to move out of their defenses, and assuming that they can move their army quickly through the fabled WILDERNESS.\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n<iframe title=\"Embed Player\" src=\"//play.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/16373606/height/200/theme/modern/size/large/thumbnail/yes/custom-color/2b3f55/download/yes\" height=\"200\" width=\"100%\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"\" webkitallowfullscreen=\"true\" mozallowfullscreen=\"true\" oallowfullscreen=\"true\" msallowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border: none;\"></iframe>\n<h2>Quotes</h2>\n<em>\"\'Man proposes and God disposes.\' There are but few important events in the affairs of men brought about by their own choice.\"\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"The foe that held his guarded hills -- Must speed to woods afar;\nFor the scheme that was nursed by the Culpepper hearth -- With the slowly-smoked cigar—\nThe scheme that smouldered through winter long -- Now bursts into act—into war—\nThe resolute scheme of a heart as calm -- As the Cyclone’s core.\"\n<strong>-- Herman Melville: The Armies of the Wilderness - First Appearance in \"Battle-Pieces and Aspects of the War\" (1866), page 107</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"Well, the movement so far has been as satisfactory as could be desired.\"\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"We have succeeded in seizing the fords and crossing the river without loss or delay. Lee must by this time know upon what roads we are advancing, but he may not yet realize the full extent of the movement. We shall probably soon get some indications of to what he intends to do.\"\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. (3112, 1, '2021-07-11 22:42:05', '2021-07-11 22:42:05', '<h1>It\'s April 1864...</h1>\n...Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant has placed his command in the field with the largest arm of the Union War Machine -- The Army of the Potomac. With his Headquarters now in Culpeper, Grant begins coordinating with the other forces arrayed around the Confederacy while also inspecting, talking to, and getting to know the soldiers of the Army of the Potomac. It is at this point that Grant has placed his trust in Meade and his senior generals to devise the opening moves of the Overland Campaign in just a few weeks.\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n<iframe title=\"Embed Player\" src=\"//play.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/16166249/height/200/theme/modern/size/large/thumbnail/yes/custom-color/2b3f55/download/yes\" height=\"200\" width=\"100%\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"\" webkitallowfullscreen=\"true\" mozallowfullscreen=\"true\" oallowfullscreen=\"true\" msallowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border: none;\"></iframe>\n<h4>Quotes</h4>\n<em>\"The only point upon which I am now in doubt is whether it will be better to cross the Rapidan above or below him.\"\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. Ulysses S. Grant</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"\'Man proposes and God disposes.\' There are but few important events in the affairs of men brought about by their own choice.\"\n<strong>-- Ethan S. (3114, 1, '2021-07-11 22:46:08', '2021-07-11 22:46:08', '<h1>It\'s March 1864...</h1>\n...Newly promoted Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant, commander of the newly formed United States Army, has decided to place his command in the field with the largest arm of the Union War Machine: The Army of the Potomac. Still encamped outside Culpeper, Virginia, this 120,000 man force has been staring across the Rapidan River at their Confederate adversaries to the South all Winter. Within the next 8 weeks, Grant will launch this army South, directly into the teeth of General Robert E. Lee and the Army of Northern Virginia, and begin the bloodiest military campaign of the Civil War: The Overland Campaign.\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n<iframe title=\"Embed Player\" src=\"//play.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/16023971/height/200/theme/modern/size/large/thumbnail/yes/custom-color/2b3f55/download/yes\" height=\"200\" width=\"100%\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"\" webkitallowfullscreen=\"true\" mozallowfullscreen=\"true\" oallowfullscreen=\"true\" msallowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border: none;\"></iframe>\n<h2>Quotes</h2>\n<em>\"The Army of the Potomac is in splendid condition and evidently feels like whipping somebody; I feel much better with this command than I did before seeing it.\"\n<strong>-- Lt.Gen. (3116, 1, '2021-07-11 22:49:56', '2021-07-11 22:49:56', '<h4>It is March 1864...</h4>\n...President Lincoln has now promoted Ulysses S. (3117, 1, '2021-07-11 22:51:28', '2021-07-11 22:51:28', '<h1>Overview</h1>\nIt is March 1864, and President Lincoln is concerned. The first real victory in the East -- The Battle of Gettysburg -- is short-lived when General George Meade, Commander of the Army of the Potomac, fails to capture General Lee and the Army of Northern Virginia before they slip back into the Virginia wilderness. Now political pressure is mounting on Lincoln with Northern Democrats and Copperheads pushing him to make peace with the Confederacy. Combined with the growing number of Union causalities, New York Draft Riots, and a mix of results in the West, Lincoln is faced with the possibility of a divided nation and the continuation of slavery in North America for generations to come. The wartime stakes could never be higher!\n<h2>Quotes</h2>\n<em>\"That Grant, he was the only War Yankee Lincoln had that was worth anything.\"\n<strong>-- Grandpa</strong></em>\n\n<em>\"The world will little note nor long remember what we say here but it can never forget what they did here.\"\n<strong>-- President Abraham Lincoln, From the Gettysburg Address</strong></em>\n<h2>Support the <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a></h2>\nThe <a href=\"https://battlefields.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">American Battlefield Trust</a> knows that there is no substitute for experiencing history in the places where it actually took place and has worked to become the only one national organization working to save America\'s historic battlefields today and discover how you can help preserve American history forever. (3121, 1, '2021-07-12 01:17:11', '2021-07-12 01:17:11', '<h1>It is March 1864...</h1>\n...President Lincoln is concerned. The first real victory in the East -- The Battle of Gettysburg -- is short-lived when General George Meade, Commander of the Army of the Potomac, fails to capture General Lee and the Army of Northern Virginia before they slip back into the Virginia wilderness. Now political pressure is mounting on Lincoln with Northern Democrats and Copperheads pushing him to make peace with the Confederacy. Combined with the growing number of Union causalities, New York Draft Riots, and a mix of results in the West, Lincoln is faced with the possibility of a divided nation and the continuation of slavery in North America for generations to come. (3128, 1, '2021-07-12 01:28:29', '2021-07-12 01:28:29', '<h1>War Yankee - Overland</h1>\nIt\'s May 1864, and the Union enters its fourth year of war against the Confederacy succession. Ulysses S. Grant -- Hero of Vicksburg -- has been promoted to General-in-Chief of the entire Union Army by President Lincoln in a last-ditch effort to win the war. Grant, placing his command in the field with the Army of the Potomac, will now execute his own aggressive strategy against the rebels and all fronts. But first, he must spend the next 47-days fighting his way across the enemy-held Commonwealth of Virginia. Join amateur historian and US Navy veteran Kyle M. Bondo, as he follows the history of Grant\'s Overland Campaign from Washington, DC, to Petersburg, Virginia, in War Yankee, an American Civil War Podcast is a history podcast presented by Gagglepod.\n\nJoin amateur war historian and US Navy veteran Kyle M. (3157, 1, '2021-10-06 04:17:53', '2021-10-06 04:17:53', '<h1>It\'s noon on May 5th, 1864...</h1>\n... Greenhorn cavalry officer Brigadier General James Harrison \"Harry\" Wilson started the Overland Campaign with high expectations. Now, after a series of tactical shortcomings and conflicting orders, his actions have allowed rebel forces to approach the Union army almost undetected. (3169, 1, '2021-10-14 14:51:02', '2021-10-14 14:51:02', '<h1>It\'s noon on May 5th, 1864...</h1>\n... Greenhorn cavalry officer Brig. Gen. Harry Wilson has stumbled onto a third Confederate cavalry force coming down the Catharpin Road. While he prepares his troopers to repeal a rebel counter-attack from his former West Point classmate Gen. Thomas \"Tex\" Rosser of Virginia, he is desperate to get this new information to Meade before it is too late. The only problem is that Wilson\'s entire cavalry division -- over 3,000 men and horses -- is completely cut off from the rest of the Union Army. No one is coming to save him or his men.\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n[PLAYER]\n<h2>Quotes</h2>\n<em>\"I had had no word from Sheridan that day and knew absolutely nothing as to his whereabouts or even as to the position of any part of the army except my own.\"\n<strong>-- Brig. Gen. Harry Wilson</strong></em>\n<em>\"Pistol and sabre were busy in slaughter while the shrieks of the stricken and the shouts of the victors mingled with the roar of battle.\"\n<strong>-- Confederate Cavalryman</strong></em>\n<em>\"General Wilson is falling back to this point, followed by the enemy. Col. Chapman reports the enemy that attacked very superior to his [force] and compelled him to retire. Wilson himself had not yet arrived and I can\'t say what I will do. (3180, 1, '2021-10-11 02:23:04', '2021-10-11 02:23:04', '<h2>Interpreting History</h2>\n<em>\"The problem with Civil War history is that all the letters home are going to have a bias. People have axes to grind, people want to make their buddies look good, and make themselves look good. The battle reports are all written from a point of view and, of course, all the reports written after the war read sort of like \'how I could have won the war if they had let me do it. All you can do as a historian is get all those accounts together read through them all, and see if there are some common threads.\"</em>\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, C-SPAN Interview with Peter Carmichael, June 20, 2014.</strong>\n<h2>Books</h2>\n<strong>Battle of the Wilderness</strong>\n<a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Battle-Wilderness-May-5-6-1864/dp/0807130214/ref=sr_1_3?dchild=1&amp;qid=1602174585&amp;refinements=p_27%3AGordon+C.+Rhea+Esq.&amp;s=books&amp;sr=1-3&amp;text=Gordon+C.+Rhea+Esq.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Battle of the Wilderness, May 5–6, 1864 by Gordon C. Rhea Esq. -- Overland Campaign Book Series (1 of 5)</a>\n\n<strong>No Turning Back</strong>\n<a href=\"https://emergingcivilwar.com/publications/the-emerging-civil-war-series/ecw-series-no-turning-back-a-guide-to-the-1864-overland-campaign-from-the-wilderness-to-cold-harbor-may-4-june-13-1864/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">No Turning Back: A Guide to the 1864 Overland Campaign, from the Wilderness to Cold Harbor, May 4-June 13, 1864\nby Robert M. People have axes to grind, people want to make their buddies look good, and make themselves look good. People have axes to grind, people want to make their buddies look good, and make themselves look good. The battle reports are all written from a point of view and, of course, all the reports written after the war read sort of like \'how I could have won the war if they had let me do it. All you can do as a historian is get all those accounts together read through them all, and see if there are some common threads.\"\n<strong>-- Gordon Rhea, C-SPAN Interview with Peter Carmichael, (3214, 1, '2021-10-13 14:36:52', '2021-10-13 14:36:52', '<h1>It\'s noon on May 5th, 1864...</h1>\n... Greenhorn cavalry officer Brigadier General James Harrison Wilson started the Overland Campaign with high expectations. Now, after a series of tactical shortcomings and conflicting orders, his actions have allowed rebel forces to approach the Union army almost undetected. To make matters worse, Wilson\'s entire cavalry division -- over 3,000 men and horses -- are missing. No one has seen or heard from Wilson since 5:00 AM. With the Orange Plank Road now engulfed by an endless column of Confederate infantry, Grant and Meade are desperate to know: Where the hell is Harry Wilson\'s Cavalry Division?\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n[PLAYER]\n<h2>Quotes</h2>\n<em>\"I had had no word from Sheridan that day and knew absolutely nothing as to his whereabouts or even as to the position of any part of the army except my own.\"\n<strong>-- Brig. Gen. Harry Wilson</strong></em>\n<em>\"Pistol and sabre were busy in slaughter while the shrieks of the stricken and the shouts of the victors mingled with the roar of battle.\"\n<strong>-- Confederate Cavalryman</strong></em>\n<em>\"General Wilson is falling back to this point, followed by the enemy. Col. Chapman reports the enemy that attacked very superior to his [force] and compelled him to retire. Wilson himself had not yet arrived and I can\'t say what I will do. (3215, 1, '2021-10-14 14:51:02', '2021-10-14 14:51:02', '<h1>It\'s noon on May 5th, 1864...</h1>\n... Greenhorn cavalry officer Brig. Gen. Thomas \"Tex\" Rosser of Virginia, he is desperate to get this new information to Meade before it is too late. The only problem is that Wilson\'s entire cavalry division -- over 3,000 men and horses -- is completely cut off from the rest of the Union Army. (3219, 1, '2021-10-14 15:18:37', '2021-10-14 15:18:37', '<h1>It\'s noon on May 5th, 1864...</h1>\n... Greenhorn cavalry officer Brigadier General James Harrison \"Harry\" Wilson started the Overland Campaign with high expectations. Now, after a series of tactical shortcomings and conflicting orders, his actions have allowed rebel forces to approach the Union army almost undetected. To make matters worse, Wilson\'s entire cavalry division -- over 3,000 men and horses -- are missing. No one has seen or heard from Wilson since 5:00 AM. With the Orange Plank Road now engulfed by an endless column of Confederate infantry, Grant and Meade are desperate to know: Where the hell is Harry Wilson\'s Cavalry Division?\n<h2>Listen Now</h2>\n<iframe title=\"Embed Player\" src=\"//play.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/20723045/height/200/theme/modern/size/large/thumbnail/yes/custom-color/2b3f55/time-start/00:00:00/download/yes/hide-show/no/direction/backward/hide-playlist/no/hide-subscribe/no/hide-share/no\" height=\"200\" width=\"100%\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"\" webkitallowfullscreen=\"true\" mozallowfullscreen=\"true\" oallowfullscreen=\"true\" msallowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border: none;\"></iframe>\n<h2>Quotes</h2>\n<em>\"My pickets report nothing new from the enemy this morning.\"\n<strong>-- Brig.Gen.
